chapterTitle: Introduction to Valuation:The Time Value of Money

columns.text: In this task, we must describe the impact of the call provisions on the desirability of securing securities as an investment for the TMCC.

This type of provision is an example of a call provision.  A call provision is a clause that permits the issuer to buy back the debt security at a predetermined price. Because they increase the risk of reinvestment, call clauses almost always make bonds less appealing as an investment option.

For this task, investing in stocks with a call option is preferable since investors may get their money back early, at the stated value, before the 30-year term ends. Take, for instance, the scenario in which you want to put $24,099 in TMCC and anticipate receiving $100,000 after 30 years. Supposing that TMCC finds a cheaper source of financing after ten years, it will "call" back the bonds, which means it will pay you a fixed quantity of money and then borrow from somewhere else. Reinvestment risk refers to the possibility that you may get a quantity of money, but then you will have to invest that money somewhere else at a lower interest rate.
For this exercise, we need to consider the security offered by TMCC is callable and we need to argue if this is a desirable trait or not for an investor.

In the case of a security-like bond that thas called provisions, meaning that the issuer added a clause that states that they are able to buy back the product after a certain time, the investor assumes an extra risk.  However, when the issuer buys back the product, if they decide to do so, they have to pay for the accumulated interest, and usually, they will add a prime.

Why would an issuer pay more to cut short their debt? 
-
This is favorable for the issuer since they can refinance debt if interest rates decreased during the maturity of the security. Say if the issuers decide to sell a product with a 5% coupon for 10 years. In year 5 the interest rates (Treasury bills) decrease from 1% per annum to 0.25%. It will be better for the issuer to buy back the product and issue a new product with the same conditions but a lower coupon, thus having a lower discount rate for their project by having "cheaper debt".

How does this affect an investor? 
-
The investor does not find itself affected in terms of loss, they can even benefit in the short term with the prime paid; However, they will lose the future cash flows project from the project. If we consider the previous example, the buyer will have the opportunity to buy a similar security from the same issuer but now the expected return rate will be lower. For that reason, it is a riskier opportunity to invest in a security with a call provision, and arguably less desirable than a security without this clause.
